channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-4063] Debugger Step Into doesn't work in Groovy-compiled classes when stepping filters are applied
item.description:
Reproduced in IntelliJ IDEA 9, GroovyEclipse 2.0 and JSWAT 4.5, therefore the problem is probably in Groovy itself.

Stepping class exclusion filters are set to ignore everything from Java and Groovy internals: groovy.,org.codehaus.groovy.,java.,sun.,org.apache.*

class Some {
	static void meth() {
		println "Method is called."
	}

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		meth()		// breakpoint here
	}
}

Run to the breakpoint in 'main' method. 'Step into'. There's a very long pause (presumably JVM applies the filters to all the underlying groovy internals), the message is printed and the program exits. Breakpoint is not hit.

Now put the breakpoint to the 'println' line in 'meth' and repeat stepping into. This time the debugger stops at it.

Stepping worked in earlier Groovy versions (e.g. 1.5) and stopped in 1.6. Therefore I suspect it to be somehow mystically related to class generation (or the libraries used, whatever)
item.summary: Debugger Step Into doesn't work in Groovy-compiled classes when stepping filters are applied

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Are there any news about the issue? Stepping still broken in all major IDEs.

The problem is, the line number information is there in the bytecode and as far as we can say it is correct. But in some scenarios the debuggers seem to have problem with certain construction... and we don't know even remotely what those problem conditions are. And no one seems to be able to tell me.
Does it work without step filtering? If yes, then it shouldn't be a Groovy issue at all. But we know there are such problems in some cases

Without step filters stepping is useless - too many groovy-generated code.
Workaround now is to set breakpoints here and there, only this way you can guarantee that you stop somewhere...
I have just checked and can confirm that it works fine in 1.5.8 and does not work in 1.6.9

I can 100% reproduce it now this way:

  • create eclipse or IDEA groovy project
  • add groovy file with the code: 
    class Some {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        def some = new Some()
        subfunction(some) //breakpoint here
        subfunction(some)
    }

    private static void subfunction(Some some) {
        println "sub"
    }
	
}
  • set a breakpoint in the line specified
  • debug the file
  • when it stops on the breakpoint hit "step into"
    It will act like if you did step over
This issue seems to be fixed now
sorry, I forgot to explain... I was able to reproduce the issue here using eclipse and made an experiment with moving the line numbers in the bytecode a bit up. That seems to have done it.
and to be very sure, I just tested you code as well and I can set break points at both subfunction call sites and let the debugger stop there
Wonderful news! Is there a build I can try it?
there should be a snapshot available in under 1h from http://ci.groovy-lang.org/repository/download/Groovy_Jdk7Build/403:id/target/distributions/groovy-binary-2.2.2-SNAPSHOT.zip?guest=1
ok, I gave the wrong link, this one is right: http://ci.groovy-lang.org/repository/download/Groovy_Jdk7Build/290:id/target/distributions/groovy-binary-2.2.2-SNAPSHOT.zip?guest=1
Still no luck Step into goes to the next line instead of the subfunction body

Out of curiosity, could it be that IDEA uses its own bundled version of Groovy, and hence not using our snapshot?
(I just want to be sure we're really testing with the snapshot)

Hi,

I've tried the same snapshot, recompiled the file, ensured that the snapshot (and not the IDEA-bundled Groovy) is used for compilation and running, disabled runtime instrumentation that removes timestamp*239 fields, and repeated the steps described by Egor. The result is the same, no dice.
Peter, any idea how Eclipse and IDEA differ in that matter, because it seems to work in Eclipse

Jochen, honestly, I have no idea. From what I know, IDEA uses the standard Java debug API, issuing step requests and setting up stepping filters (org.codehaus.groovy.* and groovy.*). We can turn on low-level debugging which tracks all the communication between IDEA and the debugged VM, but as far as I can see from these logs, there are no events from the VM regarding subfunction body.

How do you change groovy compiler in eclipse?
I tried changing the project library to snapshot's groovy-all.jar and it still does not step into.
Is there anything else I should do?

Attached is a sample gradle project that illustrates the problem.

The lib directory contains groovy-2.2.0-SNAPSHOT with your patch, Jochen.

To test:

./gradlew idea

Then open the generated project into IntelliJ IDEA. Press "debug", then step into.

so it looks like I made a mistake. I improved the debugging abilities in so far, that you can set a breakpoint anywhere and have the debugger stop there. This was not always working. But for that step into test I guess I still had that breakpoint active (sometimes there are glitches and you don't see the breakpoint in the editor). After ensuring it is not there I can confirm that step-into seems not to work properly. The line number information is there, but maybe the line number alone is not the deciding factor for step-into.

The fact that getting into subfunction without step filters is surely noteworthy.

While experimenting there I found something interesting though. I used filters for only com.sun, sun and java.lang and where it stops in subfunction is not the entry of subfunction, but when it tries to get the callsite

I also found out, that using invokedynamic compiled code step-into works. So there should be a difference in the bytecode here that is a deciding factor.

In case of standard Groovy this looks like this (using asm):

   L0
    LINENUMBER 1735 L0
    INVOKESTATIC Some.$getCallSiteArray ()[Lorg/codehaus/groovy/runtime/callsite/CallSite;
    ASTORE 1
    ALOAD 1
    LDC 3
    AALOAD
    LDC LSome;.class
    LDC "sub"
    INVOKEINTERFACE org/codehaus/groovy/runtime/callsite/CallSite.callStatic (Ljava/lang/Class;Ljava/lang/Object;)Ljava/lang/Object;

And in case of invokedynamic it looks like this:

   L0
    LINENUMBER 1735 L0
    LDC LSome;.class
    LDC "sub"
    INVOKEDYNAMIC invoke(Ljava/lang/Class;Ljava/lang/String;)Ljava/lang/Object; [
      // handle kind 0x6 : INVOKESTATIC
      org/codehaus/groovy/vmplugin/v7/IndyInterface.bootstrap((Ljava/lang/invoke/MethodHandles$Lookup;Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/invoke/MethodType;Ljava/lang/String;I)Ljava/lang/invoke/CallSite;)
      // arguments:
      "println", 0
    ]

my suspicion now is, and I must say it is based on nothing but my experience so far is, that for step-into we don't stop at the beginning of the method at all. We stop when either a method call is done, or a variable slot with line number is used.

To confirm my suspicion I let the compiler produce a variable called lineNumberTest with line information at the beginning of each method. And the result is that step-into now seems to work even with filters. It stops before the variable is assigned, not sure where exactly. But if I use step-into again, it still skips the println call.

The next test is then to use an ordinary method call. I just randomly use System.console() for that. I ensured there is a line number information before the call, but step-into failed to stop.

Next thing is then of course to check how Java compiles code like this here:

class T {
  public void f(){
    System.console();
  }
}

and on first glance the produced bytecode for f is very similar to my test case:

  public f()V
   L0
    LINENUMBER 3 L0
    INVOKESTATIC java/lang/System.console ()Ljava/io/Console;
    POP
   L1
    LINENUMBER 4 L1
    RETURN
    MAXSTACK = 1
    MAXLOCALS = 1

Looking at it a second time though I see something interesting, that is missing in Groovy... There is line information for line 4, even though there is no code in that line. If I change the code in f to return the console I get this bytecode instead

  // access flags 0x1
  public f()Ljava/lang/Object;
   L0
    LINENUMBER 3 L0
    INVOKESTATIC java/lang/System.console ()Ljava/io/Console;
    ARETURN
    MAXSTACK = 1
    MAXLOCALS = 1

and there is no line 4 at all.

so the next theory is that a non-void version should work in the example above. But I could not confirm this. The I changed the compiler to produce the line number before the return, but that also did not improve the situation

Have you tried comparing it to what version 1.5.8 compile?
Ah, I can see that the difference is too large...

my result from this and trying to get some information from one of the JVM engineers is that there is no spec for this and the only documentation is the source of the debugger, which nobody seems to know by heart. So nobody seems to be able to tell me if there is a problem on our side or how it has to look like to work.

GROOVY-8742 seems related. Line number information in class file is the reason the breakpoint does not hit. When compiling without "indy", there is a fast-path conditional added and this generates two paths through the code and both receive line number information for the visible source. This confuses the debugger.
This seems to work with 2.4.16 and 2.5.5-SNAPSHOT, I presume it was fixed by GROOVY-8742.
